Subject: Re: [neat] Re: Automatically setting the Speciation Threshold
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=7192225; y=A7vUL5UToNfy6LtrvbxaSEh69y2CaEz4G-5zAxT7w5_qPyi7Vg

Colin wrote:

>So in the general case I would like to plug in a network or genome
>comparison scheme to drive speciation in the same way that we tend to
>plug in fitness evaluation schemes. And in fact a given experiment may
>have a number of different measures we would like to keep track of and
>cluster/speciate on. I think it makes sense for some problem domains,
>but this does potentially sounds a bit like driving evolution by
>comparing phenotypes rather than genotypes - which was another
>discussion we had some time ago.
>
>Anyway I thought the specific example might be interesting.

Yes it's interesting as it brings up an interesting point.

As a general principal, I prefer any technique that "autoconfigures" 
over one that requires the user to carefully set it up for each 
problem.  So in this case, as you started your discussion, I was 
thinking it was interesting, but not very general because you were 
using domain information in order to devise a speciation strategy.

When you got to the end, however, I realized you've come full circle 
and are basically saying that we could plug-in a speciation 
comparitor in just the same way as we plug-in fitness functions.  So 
you've arrived at a far more general idea than you started with...

All that said, I'm beginning to wonder whether using "species" for 
all these different types of grouping doesn't muddy the waters a 
bit.  e.g. any scheme where individuals get assigned into species on 
the basis of a comparison sounds to me very different from any scheme 
where (for example) the species of an individual is known from its 
lineage.  e.g. dolphins and sharks look very similar, and with good 
reason, but they are not in the same species genetically.

Natural species use two methods for determining whether something is 
the same or a different species:

1) when I breed with it, are there any (viable) offspring -- e.g. all 
plants do this, they just scatter the pollen and if it hits a 
different species, never mind

2) is it an individuals opinion that another individual is a valid 
mate -- e.g. all the more-sophisticated animals do this, using a 
_lot_ of techniques to make the decision (looks, responding 
correctly, smelling right, having a Ferrarri, ...)

So although both of those do involve some sorts of comparisons, e.g. 
of sense-data in 2 and by molecule-to-molecule collisions in 1, 
neither of them is anything like as primitive (which I mean in the 
sense of "fundamental", not "simplistic") as our individual to 
individual comparisons.  I more-natural scheme might be to give each 
individual an (evolving) FID and then just call them the same species 
if their FIDs match to within some threshold.  Why does this 
matter?  Well, for example, each evolving species is a population, 
with a variety of different individuals in it, that's how its search 
works, but as soon as we assign species by direct comparison, we 
suddenly define the members of the species as all being similar to 
some degree (and we also prevent any other species from exploring the 
same individuals).  So I wonder if we hamper our species by being too 
precise in how we assign individuals.

Anyway, to get back a point or two.  "Species" created by comparisons 
would seem better named as "categories" to me, e.g. because that's 
what we did, we categorised the population...

         Ian
In 15 minutes everybody will be in the future.
